paper_title: Effect of the Defect Modulator and Ligand Length of Metal–Organic Frameworks on Carbon Dioxide Photoreduction

catalyst.source: Herein, a series of typical MOFs of the UiO family (UiO-6x-NH 2 , x 8, 7, and 6) with ligands of varied lengths and amino-group-modified defects were synthesized and employed to explore their performance for photocatalytic CO 2 reduction.
catalyst.context: The nature of defects and organic ligands can fine-tune the absorption energy (E abs ) of metal-organic frameworks (MOFs), which is crucial for photocatalytic reactions; however, the relevant studies are in their infancy.Herein, a series of typical MOFs of the UiO family (UiO-6x-NH 2 , x 8, 7, and 6) with ligands of varied lengths and amino-group-modified defects were synthesized and employed to explore their performance for photocatalytic CO 2 reduction.Sample UiO-66-NH 2 -2ABA (2ABA 3,5-diamino-benzoate) with the shortest dicarboxylate ligand and two amino-group-modified defects exhibits superior photocatalytic activity due to the lowest E abs .The CO yield photocatalyzed by UiO-66-NH 2 -2ABA is 17.5 mol g -1 h -1 , which is 2.4 times that of UiO-68-NH 2 -BA (BA benzoate) with the longest ligand and no amino group involved in the defects.Both the experiments and theoretical calculations show that shorter dicarboxylate ligands and more amino groups result in smaller E abs , which is favorable for photocatalytic reactions.This study provides new insights into boosting the photocatalytic efficiency by modulating the defects and ligands in MOFs.

light source.source: The photoreductive reactions were carried out in a gas-solid system with triethanolamine (TEOA) as the sacrificial agent and performed under a 300 W xenon arc lamp with a 400 nm cutoff filter (for details, see the Supporting Information).
light source.context: Preparation of UiO-68-NH 2 -X (X BA and 2ABA).UiO-68-NH 2 -BA was prepared as follows: 23.3 mg of (0.1 mmol) ZrCl 4 , 33.3 mg of (0.1 mmol) ATDA, and 381.5 mg of (3 mmol) BA were added into 10 mL of dimethylformamide (DMF).The mixture after being sonicated at room temperature for 30 min was sealed and reacted at 120 C for 72 h without stirring.After the reaction, the solid was isolated by centrifugation, washed with DMF, ethanol, and acetone, and dried at 150 C for 12 h.The experimental process of obtaining UiO-68-NH 2 -2ABA is the same, but by using 456.5 mg of (3 mmol) 2ABA instead of BA in the preparation of UiO-68-NH 2 -BA. Preparation of UiO-67-NH 2 -X (X BA and 2ABA).UiO-67-NH 2 -BA was prepared by the same method as that of UiO-68-NH 2 -BA, that is, by using 23.3 mg of (0.1 mmol) ZrCl 4 , 25.6 mg of (0.1 mmol) ADDA, and 381.5 mg of (3 mmol) BA in 10 mL of DMF and performing the reaction at 120 C for 24 h.UiO-67-NH 2 -2ABA was also prepared by the same process as that of UiO-67-NH 2 -BA but by adding 456.5 mg of (3 mmol) 2ABA instead of BA. Preparation of UiO-66-NH 2 -X (X BA and 2ABA).The titled samples were obtained by the same method as those of UiO-67-NH 2 -BA and UiO-67-NH 2 -2ABA, respectively, but by using 18.1 mg of (0.1 mmol) ATA instead of ADDA. Photocatalytic CO 2 Reduction Reaction.The photoreductive reactions were carried out in a gas-solid system with triethanolamine (TEOA) as the sacrificial agent and performed under a 300 W xenon arc lamp with a 400 nm cutoff filter (for details, see the Supporting Information). Computational Methods.The cluster models were constructed to investigate the influence of defects on the electronic structures of materials by performing density functional theory (DFT) and timedependent DFT (TDDFT) calculations.All the DFT and TDDFT calculations were implemented using the CP2K v7.1 software package, 293031 the basis set and functional used were DZP-MOLPLOT-SR-GTH and GTH-PBE, respectively, together with an energy cutoff of 500 Ry, 32,33 and the self-consistent field energy convergence criterion was set to be 1.0 10 -6 Ry.The HOMO-LUMO gaps of cluster models were calculated by the Perdew-Burke-Ernzerhof functional orbital composition analysis, and the density of states (DOS) calculations were carried out using the Multiwfn code. 34A Gaussian broadening function was employed for plotting the total DOS (TDOS) and partial DOS (PDOS).The Hirshfeld population analysis scheme was adopted to calculate the orbital composition.

reaction medium.source: In summary, we synthesized six samples with varied modulators and dicarboxylate ligands and applied them to CO 2 photocatalytic reactions through a solvent-free reaction route to explore the influence of amino groups in defects and the length of ligands on altering the catalytic efficiency.
reaction medium.context: In summary, we synthesized six samples with varied modulators and dicarboxylate ligands and applied them to CO 2 photocatalytic reactions through a solvent-free reaction route to explore the influence of amino groups in defects and the length of ligands on altering the catalytic efficiency.The experiments showed that UiO-66-NH 2 -2ABA with two amino groups in defects and the shortest dicarboxylate linker, forming a type-II tailored homojunction, exhibits the best photocatalytic activity among the samples.DFT and TDDFT calculations further demonstrate that the shorter ligand reduces E abs and the HOMO mainly localizes on the 2ABA modulator; hence, the higher the conjugation degree of the ligand modulator is, the more the HOMO energy level increases, contributing to the smaller E abs .Meanwhile, the lowest vertical excited states verify that the smaller E abs results in a stronger LMCT effect, which is beneficial for the photoreactions.This work shows a new prospect of optimizing properties for photocatalytic applications. compared to that produced by the benzoic acid in MOFs, which is due to its less acidic property and enhanced steric hindrance compared to that of the dicarboxylate linkers. 35It is noteworthy that the amino groups in the defects heighten the surface area and the capacity of CO 2 adsorption; for instance, the Brunauer-Emmett-Teller surface area and CO 2 adsorption capacity (Figure S10) for UiO-66-NH 2 -BA and UiO-66-NH 2 -2ABA samples increase from 593.81 to 740.24 m 2 g -1 and 13.18 to 47.46 cm 3 g -1 (at 298 K), respectively, with the same trends as that of sets UiO-68-NH 2 -BA and UiO-68-NH 2 -2ABA and UiO-67-NH 2 -BA and UiO-67-NH 2 -2ABA (Table S1).Though the samples of UiO-68-NH 2 -2ABA, UiO-67-NH 2 -2ABA, and UiO-66-NH 2 -2ABA with the shrinking length of ligands reduce the pore size as the dominant peaks of the pore size distribution shift from 2.23 to 1.57 nm (Figure S11), UiO-66-NH 2 -2ABA shows the best CO 2 adsorption capacity among the samples on account of the increased content of amino groups, which can be verified by the increasing N element atomic concentrations in the results of X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) (Table S2).Meanwhile, there are two peaks in the N 1s spectrum, representing -NH- and -NH 2 in the amino groups of UiO-66-NH 2 -BA and UiO-66-NH 2 -2ABA (Figure S12), respectively, where the peaks of -NH- red-shift from 399.33 to 399.13 eV (the same trends of sets are observed for UiO-67-NH 2 -BA and UiO-67-NH 2 -2ABA and UiO-68-NH 2 -BA and UiO-68-NH 2 -2ABA) and the binding energy of -NH- at 399.13 eV of UiO-66-NH 2 -2ABA is stronger than that of UiO-66-NH 2 -BA, implying that the additional amino groups enhance the electron transfer ability of samples. 36Moreover, the intensity of peaks increases with the shortened linkers for the Zr atom in the XPS spectra due to the increase in the electron density of the Zr cluster, and the Zr 3d peaks of both UiO-66-NH 2 -BA and UiO-66-NH 2 -2ABA shift to lower binding energy than that of the corresponding UiO-68-NH 2 -BA and UiO-68-NH 2 -2ABA, suggesting that it is easy to generate Zr 3 species and enable the fast transfer of electrons (Figure S13). 15Hence, amino-modified modulators with a shrinkable dicarboxylate ligand enhance the CO 2 adsorption and electron transfer capacity, which is beneficial for the photocatalytic ability. The orbital composition DOS of the above samples demonstrates that in the first step of photocatalysis, E abs is controlled by the HOMO and LUMO on the linker as their pristine ones, which almost equals their band gap (vide post, Figure S26). 26,37Diffuse reflectance ultraviolet-visible-near- The band gap of each sample was estimated from the corresponding Tauc plot (Figure S14), with the resulting values listed in Figure 3c, and accompanied by the presence of -NH 2 and the shrunken ligand, band gaps show a decreasing trend and are determined to be 2.78, 2.22, 2.76, 2.12, 2.72, and 2.08 eV for UiO-68-NH 2 -BA, UiO-68-NH 2 -2ABA, UiO-67-NH 2 -BA, UiO-67-NH 2 -2ABA, UiO-66-NH 2 -BA, and UiO-66-NH 2 -2ABA, respectively.The above order proves that a systematic regulated E abs (band gap) can be achieved by altering either the amino group of the modulators or the length of the dicarboxylate ligands.The intrinsic characteristics of this series are all n-type semiconductors, as reflected by the Mott-Schottky measurements (Figure S15), 3839404142 as the flat-band potential is approximately close to the conduction band minimum. 4344445 The HOMO and LUMO potentials with respect to the normal hydrogen electrode (NHE), as shown in Figure 3c, for all the as-synthesized samples show that there is not much difference between the LUMO positions of the samples; however, they show quite different HOMO positions.Moreover, the LUMO positions of these samples are all more negative than the redox potential of CO 2 to CO (-0.53 V vs NHE), indicating the feasibility of their CO 2 photoreduction potency. 46477484950 Additionally, the smaller E abs requires less light energy to excite; hence, UiO-66-NH 2 -2ABA with its defects modified by two amino groups and the shortest ligand among the samples endows the best photoresponse compared to others under visible-light irradiation. In order to survey the separation and transformation behaviors of photoinduced electrons, photoelectrochemical measurements were conducted by means of time-resolved fluorescence decay spectroscopy, photoluminescence (PL) emission spectroscopy, transient photocurrent response measurement, and electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS).Time-resolved fluorescence decay spectroscopy, whose results are shown in Figure 4a, is employed to examine the photoexcited carrier transfer dynamics of the six samples.The average lifetime exhibits a reducing trend, with the order of UiO-68-NH 2 -BA UiO-67-NH 2 -BA UiO-66-NH 2 -BA UiO-68-NH 2 -2ABA UiO-67-NH 2 -2ABA UiO-66-NH 2 -2ABA, demonstrating that the substantial contribution of the defects with amino-modified modulators and shortened ligands will inhibit the recombination of charge carriers, which is also corroborated by the weakening emission peaks in the PL emission spectra (Figure 4b).Upon light irradiation, the samples absorb light, and the electrons in the valence band are excited to the conduction band, generating a photocurrent under the electric field. 51Figure 4c shows that UiO-66-NH 2 -2ABA exhibits the strongest transient photocurrent response among the samples, and the highest current density achieved by UiO-66-NH 2 -2ABA is 4.86 times that of UiO-68-NH 2 -BA, indicating that the shortest ligand and amino-modified defects can enhance the efficiency of electron transfer.Moreover, the arc radius of UiO-66-NH 2 -2ABA is the smallest among the samples in the EIS Nyquist plots (Figure 4d), implying the best electrical conductivity capacity. 5253354 All the photoelectrochemical results indicate that the efficiency of the photogenerated charge separation and transformation are substantially increased by altering the defects and ligands, and UiO-66-NH 2 -2ABA has the highest efficiency among these samples, which can be considered as a desirable photocatalyst for CO 2 reduction. According to the above results, it is interesting to confirm whether the accelerated electrons could facilitate the photocatalytic performance.CO 2 photoreduction reactions were performed over the series of UiO-MOFs under visible-light irradiation in a solvent-free reaction route for 5 h.The sample (2 mg) was dispersed uniformly on the fiberglass ( 25 mm) along with TEOA as a sacrificial agent in the catalytic system, and the system is shown in Figure S16.Indeed, six samples exhibit distinct yields of CO photoconverted from CO 2 as CO is the only product in the gas phase monitored by a flame ionization detector in all runs (Figure S17), whereas there are no liquid product evolutions under observation (e.g., HCOOH and CH 3 OH), supported by the results of the 1 H NMR spectral measurement (Figure S18).In these samples with different modulators and ligands, UiO-66-NH 2 -2ABA, which possesses two amino groups in the modulator and the shortest linkers, exhibits superior photocatalytic activity, reaching the CO yield of 17.5 mol g -1 h -1 , which is 2.4 times that of UiO-68-NH 2 -BA, displaying the highest apparent quantum yields of the catalytic process at 700 nm, as evaluated by monochromatic wavelength-dependent irradiation (Figure S19). 55oreover, the effective photoelectron evolution rate of UiO-66-NH 2 -2ABA reaches 35 mol g -1 h -1 (Figure 5a), higher than that of other previously reported photocatalysts such as CdS-decorated UiO-66-NH 2 , MIL-MOFs, and some inorganic materials (Table S3). 25,36,56577585960616263 Meanwhile, the contributions of the individual components in achieving the catalytic activity of UiO-MOFs toward CO 2 photoreduction were assessed by various controlled experiments, verifying that the existence of the catalyst, TEOA, and light is crucial for achieving effective CO production.Further, the photostability of UiO-66-NH 2 -2ABA was evaluated by recycling experiments, as shown in Figure 5b, and the catalytic stability is still maintained even after multiple uninterrupted cycles, and the crystalline structure and morphology of UiO-66-NH 2 -2ABA are confirmed by PXRD and SEM images to have no noticeable alteration (Figure S20).In the catalytic process, TEOA undertakes the responsibility of the electron and proton donor, offering 2e -for the photoconversion of CO 2 to CO, and the degradation product is analyzed to be 2-(bis(2hydroxyethyl)amino)acetaldehyde (Figure S21). 64,65In order to uncover the definite carbon source of the reaction, a 13 C isotopic experiment was carried out using mass spectroscopy (MS) to test the generated gas product.A signal peak at m/z 29 is observed, which is ascribed to 13 CO, originating from the primary 13 CO 2 , demonstrating that CO 2 is indeed the carbon source of CO (Figure S22).In brief, the yields of production catalyzed by these samples follow the order of UiO-66-NH 2 -2ABA UiO-67-NH 2 -2ABA UiO-68-NH 2 -2ABA UiO-66-NH 2 -BA UiO-67-NH 2 -BA UiO-68-NH 2 -BA, unambiguously attesting that the photocatalytic activity changes with the type of modulators and the length of ligands as more amino groups in benzoate accompanied by shortened linkers are more beneficial for CO 2 photoreduction.Electron paramagnetic resonance (EPR) tests were carried out to interpret the process of photoreduction.UiO-68-NH 2 -BA and UiO-66-NH 2 -2ABA were studied upon irradiation for 10 min, and signals at g 2.021, 2.009, and 2.003 in the EPR spectra were observed, which originate from the reductive Zr 3 sites, 66,67 indicating that the conversion of Zr 4 to Zr 3 in the photocatalytic process is due to the ligand-to-metal charge transfer (LMCT) effect. 68The EPR signal of UiO-66-NH 2 -2ABA at 2.003 is stronger than that of UiO-68-NH 2 -BA (Figure 5c).The stronger intensity of the EPR signals implies a stronger LMCT effect with a faster speed of the photoinduced electron transfer, verifying that the reactions of CO 2 photoreduction occurring in the Zr 3 sites of UiO-66-NH 2 -2ABA are more advantageous than that in UiO-68-NH 2 -BA, corresponding to their capabilities of reducing CO 2 , which is confirmed by linear sweep voltammetry (LSV) in a CO 2 -saturated 0.5 M KHCO 3 electrolyte (Figure 5d). In order to understand the impacts of amino-modified defects and the shortened ligands on the electronic structure of the framework, DFT and TDDFT calculations were carried out to study the lowest vertical electron excitation from occupied orbitals (HOMO) to the unoccupied orbitals (LUMO) using several models (Table S4, Figures 6a andS23-S25).The calculated E abs of the cluster models are listed in Table S5, showing the same trends as that of experimental E abs .For pristine UiO-66-NH 2 , UiO-67-NH 2 , and UiO-68-NH 2 models, the HOMO is mainly localized on the dicarboxylate ligand, while the LUMO is more delocalized to the whole cluster.Upon the introduction of modulator BA, the HOMO is changed little, so the HOMOs of UiO-68-NH 2 -BA, UiO-67-NH 2 -BA, and UiO-66-NH 2 -BA are almost the same as the HOMOs of their pristine models, which are mainly localized on their dicarboxylate ligands.Interestingly, introducing -NH 2 on BA to 2ABA, the HOMOs of UiO-68-NH 2 -2ABA, UiO-67-NH 2 -2ABA, and UiO-66-NH 2 -2ABA mainly localizes on the 2ABA ligand.Meanwhile, the LUMOs of the as-synthesized samples are almost unchanged compared to the LUMOs of their pristine models.Hence, the change in E abs is mainly due to the HOMO energy level of modulators; that is, the higher the conjugation degree of the ligand modulator is, the more the HOMO energy level increases, contributing to a smaller E abs . Simultaneously, with the shrinkable ligand length, the E abs of the two sets of models, UiO-68-NH 2 -BA, UiO-67-NH 2 -BA, and UiO-66-NH 2 -BA and UiO-68-NH 2 -2ABA, UiO-67-NH 2 -2ABA, and UiO-66-NH 2 -2ABA, both decreased with the decrease in the ligand length, corresponding to the same trends of pristine UiO-66-NH 2 , UiO-67-NH 2 , and UiO-68-NH 2 , respectively, demonstrating that the shrinking ligands can decrease E abs . The first vertical excited states of these cluster models were calculated using TDDFT.Table S6 lists the detailed information of the first vertical excited states.Almost all the lowest vertical excited states are contributed by the HOMO LUMO transition.Orbital composition analysis of these frontier orbitals shows that the ligand length and ligand modulators do not affect the metal node contributions.We also calculated the DOS of all the models (Figure S26).Since the photoreaction takes place at the metal center, energy is required to excite the electrons from the ligand to the metal node.As shown in Figure 6b, the energy difference between the ligands and metal of UiO-66-NH 2 -2ABA is much smaller than that of UiO-68-NH 2 -BA, confirming the different intensities of the experimental LMCT effect.A smaller E abs results in a stronger LMCT effect, which is beneficial for the photocatalytic reactions. Further, the energy of dicarboxylate ligands and modulators was calculated to illustrate the photocatalytic mechanism of UiO-68-NH 2 -BA and UiO-66-NH 2 -2ABA (Figure 6c and Table S7).The longest dicarboxylate ligand, ATDA, with an amino group in UiO-68-NH 2 -BA absorbs light and transfers excited photogenerated electrons from the HOMO to LUMO.Then, the electrons in the LUMO of ATDA directly move to the Zr-O cluster instead of to the higher LUMO of modulator BA in defects.Hence, BA-modified defects have no effect on the E abs of the above samples due to its high energy of the HOMO.Modulator 2ABA with two amino groups in UiO-66-NH 2 -2ABA is a light-absorbing component, where the excited photogenerated electrons in the LUMO of 2ABA can move to the lower energy of the LUMO of ATA, shifting to Zr 4 through the LMCT effect for the photoconversion of CO 2 .It forms a type-II tailored homojunction, accelerating the photoelectron transfer and separation and thus improving the photocatalytic efficiency.
